instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2978: What is 820-2978? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CHGR_AMON: What is CHGR_AMON? CHGR_AMON provides DC current sense information to the SMC(System management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip). It comes from the battery charging chip that controls the laptop charger, battery charging, and creation of PPBUS_G3H(ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip depending on the logic board part number and model). This is used for sensors. If a DC current sense sensor is reading off in diagnostics, this is a place to start looking. .
definitions.CHGR_BMON: What is CHGR_BMON? CHGR_BMON goes between the ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 that charges the battery & creates PPBUS_G3H and the SMC(system management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip) and provides current sensing information on battery charging to the SMC. If diagnostics reveal an off reading or failure with the charger current sense, this is a good place to start troubleshooting..
definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMCâ€™s voltage sensors & other sensors..

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
water damage around <CHIP>U6500</CHIP>

PPBUS 12.57V but going down after 3-5 sec
PP3V42 : OK but NO green light

Reflowed <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> now PPBUS OK: 12.57V and green light came then went after unpluggled the charger
S5 Rails OK
S3 Rails NOK when shorting power pads (<RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR>)
No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>:  0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>:  3.414V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>: 3.411V

Board turning ON in SMC bypass mode

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> suggests wrong charger using 85 watt OEM mag 1?

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_ISENSE</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_BATT_ISENSE</SIGNAL> values.
Also try another charger.
Does it charge the battery?
Turns on with battery only?

Post exact resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

Isn't 2879 board?

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
It is 2879 board

Already checked R17/18: 3 Ohms R27/28: 20 Ohms
With Official Apple 85W charger the green light turns ON but still the board doesn't turn ON
When the battery plugged Green light stays green doesn't turn Orange.
Turns ON with the battery but fan ramps up to full speed: CPU getting Hot

SMC talking to battery as I can see activity on SDA and SCL bus
Once the board turns ON with the battery and plugged the charger, disconnected the battery: it stays ON with the charger only connected

<SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL>: 1.873V with both battery and charger: 2.104V
<SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_ISENSE</SIGNAL> : 0V with only battery, with both battery and charger: 0.38V then 0.422V when Fan at Full Speed
<SIGNAL>SMC_BATT_ISENSE</SIGNAL>: 0.598V  with both battery and charger: 0.6V

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>SMC_BATT_ISENSE</SIGNAL>: 0.598V with both battery and charger: 0.6V"
Too high.
Post <SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL>/BMON voltage.
Specify values for charger only, no battery.

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL>: 0.031V with charger only  
<SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL>: 0.068V with charger only

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check for corrosion around <CHIP>U5413</CHIP>; may need to change it.

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi 2Informaticos,

I'm surprised to notice that there no <CHIP>U5413</CHIP> on that <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board........interesting no?.................hummmmm!
I should maybe work with some other board schematic or think about <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Then <RESISTOR>R5431</RESISTOR> is soldered.

"Already checked R17/18: 3 Ohms"
Did you check directly between pins?

"<SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL>: 0.068V with charger only"
"<SIGNAL>SMC_BATT_ISENSE</SIGNAL>: 0.598V with both battery and charger: 0.6V"
Please confirm values.
High <SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL> can block SMC.
This will explain starting on SMC bypass...

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I came back to that board and noticed that I've lost the ppbus with the charger  (0.7V) so I decided to check with the battery only: the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> fried!
Replaced,checked R17/18 and R27/28 before putting back under power: R17/18 too high: 174Ohms checked my soldering job around ISL, found out <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> too high, replaced it.
Then PPBUS 12.67V with official 85W charger but slowly dropping down then pulsing in loop.
Reflowed <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.
Now PPBUS 12.67V solid and stable.
Machine turning ON with charger only in SMC bypass mode or with battery.

with charger only (board not turning ON ):<SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL> : 0.07V
with charger only in SMC bypass mode    <SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL>: 0.069V
with the battery only, board OFF: <SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL>: 0.07V
with the battery board ON: around 0.600V

Exact same values in same configuration for <SIGNAL>SMC_BATT_ISENSE</SIGNAL>

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check 17/18 and 27/28 again on the PINS of the ISL. I bet there?s still an issue with 17/18

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I'm mesuring 2.9Ohms directly on pins 17/18 of the ISL, if you remove around 1 Ohm of the fluke probes it's OK.

Triple Checked the soldering there shoud be OK , what do you think?

threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> is 0V with the charger and 1.8V when ON with the battery......

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Looks good...

If board always starts in SMC bypass mode, should be an I/VSENSE sensor issue.
Do you get <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
yes

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>: 3.299V

You wrote: "If board always starts in SMC bypass mode, should be an I/VSENSE sensor issue."

So I'll check all the I/V sense signals at page 39 , 43 , 44, 51 etc....
In the mean time I've noticed that it is not charging the battery as it's pulling only 30 mA, which could make sense as for security: [B] I/V sense issue ---> STOP CHARGING[/B] Am I right?

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
removed <RESISTOR>R2598</RESISTOR>, and tryied to start the board in normal mode: NOK
On the board the pin1 ( <SIGNAL>SMC_N_FOLLOW</SIGNAL> ) is still 2.5V but as removed <RESISTOR>R2598</RESISTOR>: 0V on pin 2.

Something is still preventing the SMC to turn ON the board:
I will double check [FONT="Calibri"]<SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> and [/FONT]<SIGNAL>SMC_CPU_VSENSE</SIGNAL> as they're higher that the other rails.....

threads.title: OLD <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Removed <RESISTOR>R5385</RESISTOR> for <SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL>: NOK
with <RESISTOR>R5385</RESISTOR> still removed I've also removed <RESISTOR>R5309</RESISTOR> for <SIGNAL>SMC_CPU_VSENSE</SIGNAL> still :NOK

Next step will be to remove all the resistors that bringing all the I and V sense rails to the SMC, if still not OK so in that case I would suspect the SMC.......
What do you think?
